abstracts.cdata!:
The ratings for the project were as
            follows: the outcome was satisfactory, the sustainability
            was likely, the institutional development impact was modest,
            and the Bank and borrower performance were both
            satisfactory. The lessons leaned indicate that Lesotho
            introduced Free Primary Education in 2000 and unlike Uganda
            or Malawi, the implementation is phased. The project was
            able to support the implementation of Free Primary Education
            (FPE) by constructing classrooms, providing teaching
            learning materials, training of school management and
            teachers. The choice of adaptable program loan (APL)
            instrument was appropriate for the education sector in
            Lesotho. The instrument allows longer period to achieve
            overall objectives. This is particularly important to the
            policy and institutional development aspect of the project.
            Triggers for APL need to be carefully designed. They need to
            be more realistic and not be written as if they were dated
            covenants. Though there is no a formal SWAP approach in the
            Lesotho education sector, the experience of the project
            found that informal coordination including information
            exchange among all partners can still go a long way in
            achieving solid progress on ground. Be flexible while
            conducting dialogue with Bank's clients during
            implementation as long as it is in line with the framework
            of long-term development objectives and adheres to general
            Bank procedures. Task team continuity played an important
            role in the successful implementation. The selection of
            sites for school construction is often politicized
            especially in countries where there is still a great need
            for physical infrastructure. This was the reason why project
            implementation was initially delayed. Often education
            projects have components, which involve training of
            managers, teachers and inspectors through a series of
            workshops. The initial selection criteria for the Bursary
            Program were not stringent enough.
